title: Printrbot Dual Extruder Carriage and Mount

description.text: This is a work in progress but thought I would share. This was designed to allow two wades extruders to be attached to a Printrbot. (Or a Dual Extruder Printrbot by Japica, however I may be the only person who owns one of these....) The weight of the extruders is a problem with the 2 x rods that are stacked vertically. (this was the way the extruder mount was designed when I got it from Japica). I designed the " 3rd rod x axis brackets" to be a glue on part for the current Printrbot parts, if this all works I then plan to merge the parts together as one part file and reprint. I also have been having trouble with the linear bearings on my dual carriages so I m trying these "Pillow Bushings" from Lulzbot. They seem to be very smooth, just have to get your spacing just right. PLEASE NOTE: the current files are 1st gen and I have had to do some hand work on them with a dremel and mill to get them just right for my setup. ALSO I have access to a Dimension Printer which these parts were printed off of, support material was used and most likely needs to be used. I am just trying to get my printer to work at this point in time as it was built for me and hasnt worked properly yet. If there is interest, once I get my printer up and working and the bugs worked out of the parts, I will go back and look at making the parts more single extruder friendly. I have found that gluing the top 2 pillow bushings into the cutouts of the mounts makes the part even more sturdy. **UPDATE*** I have designed a linear bearing version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:81404

comments.text: Did you succeed mate? I am about to buy a PrintrBot Plus and I am interested in adding a second extruder
comments.author: FherraZ

comments.text: I have to calibrate the off set yet (I ve been really busy at work) but I do have it together and working and have had successful prints run out of each extruder, separately. I actually didn't get this part working and I ended up designing another one that is the one I am using now. I have it on here and I think the link is on this page. It uses the linear bearings and one of these pillow bushings for the new 3rd rod. I also ended up not using the top linear bearing, so there would be less friction. A linear bearing on the bottom and pillow bushing on the 3rd rod seem to work well. I be found the tricky part is getting the 2 extruders at the same height from the bed. I all try to get pics of the finally set up on here soon. Good luck with your printer, let me know if you have any other questions I d be happy to help!

description.text: Write a word and print it out! This isn't a 3D design, it's a 3D-design tool. The demo files are just examples; press "Open in Customizer" to get started with your own design. The Text Tool utilizes the "text" function in OpenSCAD through the MakerBot Customizer so that you can create a quick 3D model of any word or phrase. The letters can be imported for use in any other design program as part of a larger design. (The example picture shows some simple designs using the Text Tool output in Tinkercad, including a trophy cup shape from rocketboy's model http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:82860.) Much thanks to tbuser and atartanian for creating the Customizer that makes this tool possible! Also again to atartanian for the idea of making a base web with offset/inset. Thanks also to to wstein for wrangling the Google font list into something nice to use in OpenSCAD!

Toy block in cube, rectangular prism, cylinder and hexagonal prism variations, ready to print. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/d3NwUmfX934

I printed these on my RepRapPro Ormerod 2, using coloured PLA. I used 10% infill, 200 degrees Celcius for the extruder, 56 degrees Celcius for the bed, 3 solid layers on the bottom and 5 solid layers on top. 5% infill also worked fine but the top wasn't quite as nice.   
I found they printed best one at a time, because otherwise the different heights resulted in the printer changing the seam location part way through the print (as the shorter blocks were finished).  This would probably not be a problem printing multiples of the same block, or if your printer settings prevent the seam location moving.   
I tried sanding off the corners on one to make them more kid-friendly, but decided it was unnecessary for my 1 year old nephew.
Originally designed for my Fusematic, it can be mounted on any printer with aluminum extrusions.
.2mm layer height, 50% infill works like a charm!

Check out the description here: http://www.appropedia.org/Printable_Breast_Pump. Sorry, these are SolidEdge Academic Files, so they will not be able to open on commercial software. Also, don't use these to make money, or else the people at SolidEdge may get angry. I have uploaded .stl files as well. Happy printing! I am trying to find a better thread design, as this was adapted using measurments taken from a bottle. If anybody has seen a public domain model that is actually made by a company that produces these things, let me know!

Printing: So, as I have not printed this thing yet, the instructions are a bit lacking in tips and such. Check the assembly file to get a good idea of what it looks like. It should go like this:

  • Print the nipple shield. You should modify this to cup the breast well and also so that the nipple fits in the end bit.

  • Turn the nipple shield over. Zero the RepRap (or similar) in the centre of the hole on the back. Print the "NippleShieldPipeMount" on the back. Sorry for the names, they were originally working titles but I grew attached... You might need to clamp the Nipple Shield in order to stop it moving.

  • Print the Bottle Top. The threads have some overhang, so it might be a bit hairy. Play with it, tell me how it goes. Print the two more NippleShieldPipeMounts on the back of the bottle top. Finally, print two of each of the pipes. They are mirrored, so no left and right to worry about.

  • Put the two halves of each pipe together, clamp or weight while they lay flat, and put them in the oven at slightly lower than the melting temp of the polymer you are using (I recommend HDPE...good properties with food, fairly high melting temp. An oven temp of 250F should do). Watch closely! They should stick together after being in there for a while... think sintering, but for plastic. There are two, one layer thick (0.3mm for the RepRap) bands around the flow channel; these should fuse together due to the increased pressure.

  • Put it all together. The tapers should fit, but you might have to file/sand/push.

  • Use it (if you are a nursing mother... if not, kinda weird)!
    • Operation:

  • Sanitize using boiling water

  • Find a bottle that fits. Sanitize this. Screw it on. A glass bottle works best, and you can modify the lid to fit it. It is currently for a Coke bottle, because they are ubiquitous.

  • Place some petroleum jelly on the seals, assemble.

  • Place the breast in the cup, and try to get a good seal around the nipple. Again, some water or jelly might help (this is a potential issue.. maybe a softer plastic in here might help. Something to think about...)

  • Place the end of the other tube in your mouth. Gently start sucking, mimicking a baby. You want a pulse every few seconds. Change the pressure you use, and stop if it hurts. Breath through your nose, or you will pass out! The suction is created with the tongue, not the lungs!

  • Empty the breast of milk. This will help avoid clogged milk ducts and might also increase the amount you are producing.

  • Pasteurize by placing the bottle in a just boiled pot of water. This is not strictly necessary, but good if you have a transmittable infection, such as HIV.

  • Feed to your baby! A bottle nipple to follow...

  • Breast milk can be left unrefrigerated for a few hours, refrigerated for a few days, and frozen for a few months. Ask your doctor or lactation consultant!

comments.text: Has anyone made one of these and used as intended?
comments.author: bathrobotics

comments.text:
Hey Bathrobotics,
I never did print it, but when my wife is lactating, its happening. Not sure if I would feed the milk that is expressed though. Food safety wise, I would probably not use it as a regular pump. It is a neat thing, but the filament that is sold for 3d printers is likely not intended for contact with food. A silicone breast cup is probably much more comfortable anyways. If you do print one, let me know how it goes! -John

description.text: This is a spacer for http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:705345. Print 2 and put one in either side of the spool. It acts as a bushing and gains a little more clearance between the spool and printer. It also prevents the spool from cocking to one side or another. Over all it just makes it easier on the extruder and satisfies OCD.

Print 2 on medium resolution with an M3D. Use Full or High fill.  
PLA seems to work very well.

author: Majosan

description.text:
Most of my parts are pretty short, so I don't mind mounting the spool a little lower on my Taz (but i haven't had any problems even with prints around 120mm in height)  
This works well because it's so short:  the forces the spool exerts on it are so close to where it sits on the Taz frame, that there's no way it can fall over.  
The slight arch on the bottom deflects just enough to push out into the frame a little more, and the bumps on the top keep the spools in the center.  
I recommend ABS for this, as PLA might deflect over time?

This is a scooter holder.  For those of us that have kids with scooters that don't fold up, this printed object will hold the scooter upright so that the ends of the handles don't rub on the ground.  
Please note that at this point this is a prototype, I haven't printed it yet.  
I've included the original file used to create this design in OpenSCAD.  If you want to change the name that is embossed in the base, just change the variable vtext.  If there are more then 6 characters in the name, you might have to reduce the text size.  
If you have any problems, please leave me a message here.  
Thank you and happy trails....

Direct replacement for Electric Bubblegum skateboard pulley cover. Not sure if it will fit on anything else. General Print settings to get you started settings assume ABS plastuc
  • ONLY Print using High-temp high impact plastic, ABS or stronger. PLA does not work, it will melt.
  • Layer Height .20mm 5 outer layers
  • Infill 60% Hexigon
  • Print Speed 60mm/s
  • Temp 225c extruder 115c bed
  • Supports set to 75degree overhang threshold.
  • Always print on a glass bed using acetone slurry that is 95% acetone 5% abs filament by volume.
    • If you need any special pieces made or would like to buy any of my parts pre-printed or electric skateboard electronics please email me at [email protected]

The initial idea was to print tiny springs, which was just not possible on this scale. I will reprint the parts and use foam instead of spings...

The next version will have no non-functional springs but rather require foam and glue to make the elements pressable.

author: Schorhr

description.text:
A stable stand for an iTouch (4th Generation) supported in portrait mode. It works in landscape mode too, but not quite as well.  
No idea if it will fit earlier or later generations of the iTouch, since they vary slightly in width and depth.  
A nice feature is that it collapses flat for travel.

Print with100% fill.  
The individual pieces will print most cleanly and with minimum stringing; the complete stand is included if you want to print it all at once, though you may need to do some cleanup on the verticals and the bottom of the base.  
The uprights simply push into the receivers on the base from the front. They are a tight fit at first, but quickly wear in.  
To hold the pieces together when collapsed, assemble them as in the picture, hook a rubber band over the notches in the uprights from in front, take it around the back and forward over the front, and hook it over the uprights again.

author: osgibson

title: Printrbot Simple Maker 1405 Z Axis Stabilizer

description.text:
Version 1:  Smooth rod and acme screw stabilizer for 1405 Simple.  Improves z axis wobble that translates to x & y waviness as you go up in Z.   
For best results, drill out the rod holes to 5/16" or 8mm and drill out the acme screw hole to 1/4".   Apply a little bit of grease to keep it quiet.  
In the comparison picture, top left is before brace and bottom right is with brace.  
You may want to check your max Z height as the Y carriage can hit it if you go up too far.

Make sure your acme screw is all the way in the motor clamp that it is touching the motor.  
This was printed at 0.3mm layer height with 20% infill.   
Drill out rod holes to 8mm or 5/16".  Drill out acme screw hole to 1/4".  May require some force to install.

comments.text: I made the mistake of drilling out the lead screw hole an extra 1/64" over 0.25" and It was too big. Currently printing another and will post my results. Thanks for saving me the trouble of drawing this.

This TX8 design has more parts than my other “unibody” T-Copter designs. The result is a more complicated assembly procedure but that comes with the advantage that the longest print is only around three hours (compared to 10+ hours for the other larger designs). Before you start printing this design please check that your printer is big enough. The plates require at least 160 x 170mm build area and the arms are 225mm long (although you may be able to print them on an angle to fit a slightly smaller bed). Check out the whole "T" copter family:
  • T6 Hexacopter
  • T4 Quadcopter (10" props)
  • T4 Quadcopter Mini 315 (7-8" props)
  • T4 Quadcopter Mini 250 (5" props)
  • Tubular Crossfire 2 quadcopter
    I've added a post on the forums over at DIY Drones for discussing and improving these designs.

• completely 3D printable (without support)
  • light but powerful X8 design
  • strong braced tube section arms with plenty of room to conceal motor wiring. Arms can be folded down or removed altogether for transport.
  • designed for a dual 3S or 4S batteries located near the center of rotation/thrust with room for up to two 6000mah 3S or 4200mah+ 4S batteries (160 x 50 x 35mm capacity each).
  • plenty of space to mount dual 4 in 1 ESCs - concealed but still well ventilated for cooling.
  • floating vibration reducing top plate is designed for the Pixhawk flight controller](http://store.3drobotics.com/products/3dr-pixhawk) from 3D Robotics - but is also fine with others
  • RF "invisible" frame - as opposed to carbon fiber or aluminium
  • Assembly instruction PDF in the downloads
  • 2 x 5000mah 3S batteries gives 15+ minute flight time (and there's space for bigger batteries).
  • all up weight for my build (see instructions tab) comes in at 2.65kg including batteries, camera and gimbal - and hovers at about 45% throttle.
  • Sketchup CAD file is included so you can make changes to suit yourself.

• First flight with Tarot Gimbal and Go Pro attached
  • Another flight - at the river this time
  • Tubular arm versus "conventional" arm design

See the instructions PDF in the downloads. To build mine I used:
  • 3DR Pixhawk flight controller with GPS and telemetry.
  • 8 x 880kv 3DR motors (old ones recycled yet again!)
  • 8 x 10x4.7 slow fly APC props
  • 2 x Q Brain 4 in 1 ESCs
  • Spektrum satellite receiver
  • Tarot T2D gimbal (old one which is a bit bent :))
  • GoPro Hero 3+ silver
  • 2 x 5000mah 3S batteries gives 15+ minute flight time (and there's space for bigger batteries).
  • all up weight with batteries, camera and gimbal is 2.65kg and hovers at about 45% throttle.

Please excuse these comments if you are an experienced builder :)
1) run a motor test (1 motor at a time) and ensure that it is the correct motor that spins, the right direction, and that it is pushing air down.
2) ensure that all props are the right way up. Above will help with that but can be confusing as the bottom props need to be fitted upside down with respect to their motors - eg on APC props the writing should be facing the sky on all 8 props.

comments.author: Jglow

comments.text: Hi John.  It's been a while since I've done a new build so I'm bit out-of-the-loop on current motors.  For props I've always used APC 10x4.7 slow fly props and you'll need 4 "normal" and 4 "pusher" props.  In the case of the X8 you'll have one of each on each arm (top and bottom) - which one is on the top will depend on whether the top motor is running clockwise or counter-clockwise.

You'll need to print a set of the same design to hold a tablet. There are three STL files currently included.
The "In-Lean" versions will make the tablet lean in over the top of the M3D slightly, while the "Out-Lean" version will make the tablet lean off towards the outside of the M3D. The difference between the two "In-Lean" are due to the fact that the extruder casing could potentially bump into the tablet on extremely tall prints that extend to the maximum width at the highest possible print settings. To remedy this I've also included an "In-Lean Safe" version which will stop this from being an issue, but it doesn't look as good as the others. The choice is up to you on which "In-Lean" version you use, just be sure to print a set of the same STL. Specifically made to support a WinBook TW700 (http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00QDJ2FUK) which I use to run the M3D Micro without it needing to be connected to my main desktop. You'll need to use the M3D software to rotate this part to fit on the print bed -- but it IS designed to fit within the build surface.

In-Lean (Safe)
Position: X=54 Y=45
Yaw: 58 In-Lean
Position: X=54 Y=51
Yaw: 70 Out-Lean
Position: X=60 Y=51
Yaw: 30

description.text: here is a whole kit to take your power supply and finish it off. models for each end cap, the rubber cushion feet and a strain relief for the cord going to the printer.  read instructions for some tips. the ones in the pic were printed in esun petg and painted.

the strain relief and feet are printed in ninjaflex. print the feet with 2 perimeters and 15% infill. it makes them squishy for shock absorption and not too hard. the strain relief can be printed solid. its designed to flex just enough when printed solid. the psu shown is a meanwell 400 watt. i think the dimensions are the same for the 360 and 450 but double check that. the rubber feet are attached with some 3m automotive double sided tape this is the power cord: http://www.newark.com/volex/vl-0136-14-200k/power-cord-nema5-15p-iec-2m-15a/dp/46M3028?ost=46M3028 and the switch: http://www.newark.com/cherry/cre22f4bbbne/switch-rocker-spst-20a-250v-black/dp/01M7235?ost=01M7235

comments.text: yes it is painted as well. the psu comes apart very easily. few screws for the cover and a few for the board inside

title: Open Beam Clip on Mount for 15x15 extrusion

description.text: I was trying to find an easy/fast way to mount various things to my 15x15 Open Beam extrusions. I downloaded a few things, but nothing worked that great for my application.  So I ended up just modeling something that seems to work pretty well.  Feel free to use or modify if you like.  It has an m3 nut trap (I use needle nose pliers to squeeze the nut in to place) and of course an m3 bolt.  I added a negative space on both sides to help pull off the Open Beam extrusion if needed.  Without that, it's a pain to pull off...
Modeled in Maya and Printed with Slic3r.

author: Regisder

description.text:
Simple mount for a dial indicator to check that the bed is level and if it is warped or not.
Held in place just by gravity and a V-grove to key on to the front gantry rod.
9.5mm hole for the dial indicator.
Good for 40 to 50mm rod spacing Carefull not to push down on the dial as your taking a reading as the gantry rods will bend slightly at the slightest pressure throwing off the reading. If printed in ABS it should have a good friction fit for the 9.5mm shank of a dial indicator, if printed in PLA or if the hole is too loose I have Included a nut retention slot and a hole for a ~2.7mm screw. A slightly over sized bolt may not need a nut. If you have a oddball hole size requirement let me know in the comments and I will see if I can mod it for your dial indicator. 3-1-16: Added 8mm shank version.

Specially-designed for the ZENI Kinetic Origin at ProVolt. This should fit snugly onto the end of the filament feed tube. Put a bit of foam inside to keep dust off the filament as it goes to the extruder head.

• Print out two of this Thing.
  • Break the inner 3 semi-circles, as they are support material.
  • Cut a piece of foam, sponge, etc, to fit snugly inside.
  • Use two zip-ties to close this Thing together.
  • If it's sized correctly, the nozzle on the top should fit tightly onto the end of the filament feed tube.
  • Feed your filament through the sponge/foam (you will need to punch through it the first time).
    • As filament runs through the sponge/foam, this Thing will wipe off any dust and other impurities, helping keep the extruder from getting clogged. Since the ZENI Kinetic Origin has two extruders and two feed tubes, so you should make two of this Thing.

description.text:
-DailyEarrings & Prologue: www.wap.cc & thingiverse.com/thing:7120 The 100 clear wedding decoration "diamonds" from ebay arrived today; They look much better as on the product images.
Initialy I intended to color their back in a metal color, as the green one I used earlier has a reflecting aluminum coating. Now I am thinking about testing more colors, if they look just as nice (and not as plastic-y as the photos suggested). Anyway, here are the details! Perhaps I will tinker with this file a bit in the future to improve it :-)

Printed on an pp3dp UP, no clue how to on other printers. But it's small, so you might as well try it. 1- Print the stone holder
1.1 "standing" or "laying"
Printing it on the opening will require you to clean them so the diamond clips in, but printing on the round side will squish it a bit and create a rougher surface. 1.2 and low support angle, but make sure there's enough support/raft so it will not come loose!) 2- print the earring loop box (scale to 110-120% for better fit!) 2.1 The stones will clip into the holder similar to the snake diamond holder, but you need to bend it harder to slide them in. Still carefully!!! After three diamonds are in, snap the holder box in. It's a bit tricky, but should be no problem ;-)

author: Schorhr

description.text:
This is my version of a fusion between the CyClop and FreeLSS laser scanners. It uses the software/electronics of the FreeLSS and the hardware of the Cyclop. The turn has been modified to take a Nema 17 0.9deg 48mm stepper instead of the 40mm and the rest of the turntable can be found here:
http://diwo.bq.com/en/ciclop-released-2/ Software and electronics: http://www.freelss.org/ The laser clamps and holders I got from Bill Owens: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:678659/#files The PiBox I remixed from a design that I found here:
https://grabcad.com/library/raspberry-pi-b-board-and-case-1 Printed using Simplify3d and you are going to need lots of supports. I still need to do a proper write up on the instructions Update: I did 2 scans with the scanner and I posted the results from some second scan after some rendering in Meshlab. Update: Spotlights for the PiClop now available: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:799671 Diffusers for lights: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:810178

description.text:
DO NOT SCALE!  The files are specifically sized to match braille.  Any scaling could render it unreadable.  
This label pack is intended for use with mathematical or engineering models so that a blind learner or colleague will have frame of reference to the 3D tool.  It is my recommendation that you only print labels on the side as the bottom will be an additional challenge and the top will normally have reference from another face.  I will be updating this pack with more letters, but at this time it contains 10 which would be two more than what is necessary for labeling a cube.

These models were made with the modified OpenSCAD app.  Each were outputted from the app.  They are labeled with the braille letter sign(signifiying a single letter in isolation) the capital sign (showing that is a capital letter), then the letter.

description.text: Simple spinning top. Resize according to your liking.
Just glue the two parts together

A case for sim racing dashboard. It has places for speedometer, tachometer and current gear indicators. In the back is a place for a USB B-type connector. It can easily any kind of electronics to do the job. If everyhing would be on one board, the case could be much thinner, if that is preferred.

Electronics inside were built from scraps of old computers and some board (which didn't even have strips on it). A PIC microcontroller is handling everything in the device. Configuration and data to show is receiven from a PC with serial commucation over USB.  
PIC firmware just translates the received data to be shown on 7-segment displays and LEDs. A configured ratio of RPM is shown with green, yellow and red tachometer LEDs.

I have written plugins or other tools for couple of games to get speed, current gear, RPM and maximum RPM data for the device. Data is sent directly to devices virtual serial interface. At the moment these games are supported:
  • rFactor 2
  • DiRT Rally
  • RaceRoom Racing Experience
  • Euro Truck Simulator 2 (and very likely other trucking games by SCS)
  • Assetto Corsa
  • F1 2015 (and possibly other versions)
    • Original FreeCAD files are included for easy modification. Schematics, firmware and PC software can be made available if someone is interested.

comments.text: how do you conveter the free cad files to STL files after modifing the dash
comments.author: emrev

comments.text:
• Select the object to export (by double clicking on it or select it from Model view)

  • From menus select File -> Export

  • In the Export file dialog, set "Save as type" to "Mesh formats (.stl .ast .bms .obj .off .ply)"

  • Give a filename ending with .stl

  • Click Save

title: Modular Support (Case) for Arduino and Raspberry Pi - CustoBlocks
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
With CustoBlocks you can build customised frame exactly as you need, just connect blocks in the way you like! All elements fit each other, you can extend your project infinitely
no matter what block or colour you are going to add. Currently available blocks:
  • Arduino Uno / Leonardo
  • Arduino Uno / Leonardo + Breadboard Double Block
  • Raspberry Pi B+ / 2B
  • Raspberry Pi B+ / 2B + Breadboard Double Block
  • Breadboard
    • If you would like to edit this model or make something similar please use the link below:
    https://www.fiverr.com/p3d_lab/do-cad-parametric-modelling-for-3d-printing

• Connect each block with minimum 2 of M2 10mm srews.
  • Attach electronic board (Raspberry, Arduino) using 4 * Pozi srew No2
  • Stick a breadboard if you using it.
    • That's it!

comments.text: I'm having trouble printing the parts with the cone-shaped "pillars".  The "foot" of the pillars intersect the base of the main object, creating an overlap of solids in 3-D space.  This appears to be confusing my slicers.  The result is a boolean subtraction of the overlapping region leading to disconnected islands floating in space and voids in the part.  I have reproduced this in both Simplify3D and ReplicatorG (Skeinforge).  Am I doing something wrong here? and/or What slicer have you used successfully? Also Could you send me the source code as well for this model, I could make the adjustments to work with my slicer.
comments.author: PurdueJay

comments.text: I have exactly the same problem using Simpily3D  - did you find a solution?
comments.author: PurdueJay

comments.text: I'm using slic3r with no problem at all, I've tested it on Cura with no problem as well. I've never used Simplify3D or ReplicatorG so I can't help with this. If they not intersect the base, slicer may tell that object is not manifold - this is why I did it. This is designed with Blender, I can send you editable files, just PM you email to me. Thanks.

comments.text: If anyone is wondering about the display on my FlashForge Creator Pro...  I replaced the original LCD (white/blue) with a Vacuum Florescent Display.  It is a Noritake CU20045-UW5J.  The board on the FlashForge Creator Pro has a 16 pin header.  The last two are used for the backlight, which is not used by the VFD.  Solder a pin header to the 14 pins of the VFD, slightly enlarge the four mounting holes and install back into the case.  It will be a very tight fit, and might bow the front plastic cover out just a tiny bit, but it's much easier to read at any angle.  They're pricy ($85), but they look great.  I have tried an OLED display, but either it wasn't compatible or something was faulty on the display board…text was garbled from time to time.

description.text:
This spool holder allows you to print with the lid of your Press open, without having to have the spool sitting alongside the printer. This means you don't need any additional table space.  
The screw cap was taken from the "SilverBullett" download as I was too lazy to design my own!

The prop ensures that the lid stays open. See the pictures for how to use this item.  
To fit the spool holder, hold the screw cap/retainer inside the lid whilst pushing the spindle through. Rotate the spindle from the top to screw it into the retainer.

author: Cdaddy

title: KIS extruder - direct drive Nema 17 & Mk8 for 1.75 filament

description.text:
KIS-(Keep It Simple) Mk1 extruder for 1.75 filament
Using ideas from all over the net i have developed a simple adjustable tension DD extruder based on a Nema 17 & Mk8 filament drive bush. The push fit for bowden tubes is based on the items supplied by E3D with their V6 kit.
The fitting sits in a 10mm dia hole 10mm deep and once in place a 2mm drill is used to drill through the printed holes and drill the sides of the push fit fitting. Following which 2 short lenghts of 1.75 filament can be inserted to secure the fitting in place. In itself quite secure and stable but to be on the safe side i use a small amount of hot glue as well.
Parts list
Mk8 drive bush
Spring ( 8mm OD X 18mm long)
Allen socket head M3 X 20mm > 3 pcs
Allen socket head M3 X 16mm > 1 pc
Allen socket head M3 X 12mm > 1 pc
Allen socket head M4 x 10mm > 1pc
M3 plain washer
SKF bearing 624-2Z
As an alternative spring guide bolt, a single Allen head M4 X 10 can be used ...(same bolt as holding the bearing in place) (as in the phtoto) in place of the M3 X 12 & M3 plain washers

Update 8th April 2015> Lever and body updated to R1
Minor geometry updates to improve pinch action on filament
Update 5th Apr 2015 > added a couple of simple bracket options which both require longer screws ( M3 X 25)

UPDATE 20150503: Included original pinion/gear for completeness.
UPDATE 20150412: New rack in 2 depths. I'm using the 11mm version for a good mate with the gear. Old rack removed.
UPDATE 20150406: I had to pack out the bottom dremel mount by about 1mm to get it vertical and the rack by about 1mm to improve the gear interaction. I'm working on an improved rack (pending print and testing). I've added a new height adjustment clip that's inserted below the spring to increase the height (in 10mm and 20mm variants).

I like the drill press by mitchnajmitch but wanted to make some tweaks, additions, and reduce the required filament. I really like how this turned out but already have a few more tweaks and additions in mind. Printed in PLA, 0.3mm layer, 3 perims/top/bottom, 25% honeycomb infill except for the knob which is 16% honeycomb infill. I used 5/16 threaded rod because that's what I had but you can use 8mm. Smooth rod is 8mm. Threaded rod holes are 7mm so they can be tapped (use a tap, it's much easier/better). All bolts are M3 and the nuts press fit. Parts
  • M3 bolts (and nuts): 30mm x 4, 25mm x 1, 20mm x 8, 16mm x 5.
  • Springs: 10mm inner diameter x 2.
  • Screws x 4 for fixing the base to some board or your bench.
  • LM8UU bearings or 3D printed equivalent x 4.
  • 5/16 or 8mm threaded rod: 15cm x 1, 10cm x 1.
  • Nuts for threaded rod: Regular nuts x 5 and lock nuts x 2 or, regular nuts x 6 and lock nuts x 1. 3 or 4 washers. Press fit a regular nut into the handle elbow and the gear.
  • 8mm smooth rod: 30cm x 4.
    • Modifications
  • Top: New.
  • Base: New. Designed to be fixed to a board or your bench and provides more work area.
  • Clamp: Rounded corners.
  • Rack: New. Full length in 2 depths. I'm using the 11mm version for a good mate with the gear. Countersinks for bolt heads.
  • Slider: Rounded corners and added down arrow cutout.
  • Slider Bearing Cap: Rounded corners.
  • Handle Elbow: New. Smaller.
  • Handle Knob: New.
  • Dremel Top Mount: Added nut countersinks for them to press fit.
  • Dremel Bottom Mount: Added nut countersinks for them to press fit.

Supports the spindle of the Ctc-printer. Might fit to other chinese printers. After this mod your Plate will be less shaky and more precisely. Screw holes are made for M5 screws.
You also need a 5x16mm bearing.

Print it how ever you like.Press in the bearing, mount it onto the tip of the Z-axis and mark the holes. Turn the Stabilizer 90° and drill the holes. You can drill the holes 4.2mm and screw in M5 screws directly into the wood case or drill it larger and use washers and nuts. Following settings worked fine for me on a CTC printer.
  • PLA Filament
  • 230°C Nozzle / 120°C Heat bed (blue taped)
  • 3 Shells / 15% Infill
  • 0,1mm Layer hight
  • 130mm/s speed while extruding

description.text: See http://www.appropedia.org/Printable_Baby_Bottle for details! This is a simple top that can be screwed onto a standard "Coke" bottle sized screw top to make it a baby bottle! This was made to complement this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7536. I do not take responsibility for the safety or functionality of this thing. Please use common sense, and if you do make one, post feedback! This is all done with the student edition of SolidEdge. You won't be able to open it in any other version. Please don't sell this or anything, as that will make the good people at SolidEdge angry. I have also uploaded .stl files. I am trying to find a better thread design, as this was adapted using measurments taken from a bottle. If anybody has seen a public domain model that is actually made by a company that produces these things, let me know!

Instructions:
  • Print on something like a RepRap. Use maximum infill to prevent porosity, which could cause leakage.
  • Print the bottle cap to begin with. This minimize overhang, although there is still some overhang in the thread area. Watch this carefully, to make sure that the threads form well. You might have to experiment a little to get it just right.
  • Flip the bottle cap over, and zero the printing machine (set the origin) in the very middle of the hole on the back. You might need to clamp down the bottle cap.
  • Print the nipple. The inside passage tapers very gently, at an angle much greater than 45 degrees. This degree of overhang usually does not produce issues with the RepRap.
    • NOTE!! The flow rate will be dictated by the size of the hole in the nipple. Start with a very small hole, and increase it in small increments. The bottle should slowly drip when held upside down, and the pressure should need to be equalized by turning the bottle right side up periodically. Test it first, or it could overwhelm and choke the baby! If you are using a flexible bottle, don't squeeze it, or it will increase the flow even further. Thanks to Rusted Robot for the heads up, and also for the suggestion of an alternative use: squeezable salad dressing/condiment bottle!
  • Sand carefully, and check for loose pieces that could cause the baby to choke. Sterilize with boiling water.
  • Put it on your favourite Coke bottle, and feed away! If you want to use a different bottle, just modify the cap and post it so others can use it!

comments.text: I don't think that there is a huge amount of risk with this. First off, if you have ever fed a baby, you'll know that if you give it too much food or milk or anything, they will let you know by turning their head, and spitting it all over you. Second, we come into contact with plastics all the time. Children put these things in their mouth, and there are lots of safe thermoplastics out there.
comments.author: staffert

comments.text: I guess if you're a parent, you're not necessarily looking for a print to just put into your baby's mouth. While kids put a lot of things in their mouth, I doubt that there's one parent who prints with, doesn't read the warning.

comments.text: Well, it is a hard plastic nipple for a coke bottle. Also, its sized too small to work out of the box. So a "yahoo" would be nearly making a model from scratch to put it on a baby bottle, and try to get a kid to drink out of it. And lets not forget the difficulty of getting DIY FDM water-tight. I can understand the concern, but I think its not necessary. Just my fat opinion. Perhaps change the title to "Beer Nipple" might curb child usage? :) Better yet, Liquor Nipple, lol.

title: Printrbot Simple Metal fan upgrade & Cable holders

description.text:
The fan add-on is to solve the problem with the extruder motor overheating when doing large prints. Fan details
Voltage:12V
Dimensions: 50mm × 50mm
Hole distance 40mm C/C 6mm On/Off Switch I used a hot glue gun to secure the cable holders onto the motors.

I wired the12V fan directly to the Printrbot power plug (circled blue in the wiring photo) Take care not to dislodge the Z-probe plug (circled red in the wiring photo). I had a problem just after installing my fan that the Z-axis would home upward and ignore the Z-probe input, Removing the z-probe wire from the bunch seems to have fixed the problem for now.
